SINTAX rapid taxonomic classifier for amplicon sequences.

Implements the SINTAX algorithm which uses 8-mer word matching and bootstrap resampling to classify sequences against a reference database without requiring a training step.

Reference: Edgar RC. SINTAX: a simple non-Bayesian taxonomy classifier for 16S and ITS sequences. bioRxiv 074161; doi: 10.1101/074161

Types

SintaxHit = object
  rankNames*: seq[string]    ## Taxonomy rank strings (e.g. ``"d:Bacteria"``)
  rankProbs*: seq[float]     ## Bootstrap confidence for each rank (0.0â€“1.0)
  strand*: char              ## Matched strand: ``'+'`` (forward) or ``'-'`` (reverse complement)
Result of a SINTAX taxonomic classification. 
SintaxIndex = object
  taxStrings*: seq[seq[string]] ## Per-sequence parsed taxonomy ranks

Prebuilt k-mer posting-list index for SINTAX classification.

Constructed from a reference database by buildIndex. taxStrings holds per-sequence rank arrays; the posting lists allow O(1) lookup of which sequences contain a given 8-mer.

SintaxState = object

Reusable per-thread workspace for batch SINTAX classification.

Initialise once with initSintaxState and pass to sintaxWithState for each query to avoid repeated heap allocation.

Procs

proc buildIndex(seqs: seq[string]; taxStrings: seq[string]): SintaxIndex {.
    ...raises: [KeyError], tags: [], forbids: [].}

Builds a k-mer posting-list index from reference sequences and taxonomy strings.

Each sequence in seqs is paired with the corresponding entry in taxStrings. All overlapping 8-mers in each sequence are indexed into packed posting lists for fast word-match lookups during classification.

Parameters

  • seqs â€” reference DNA sequences
  • taxStrings â€” taxonomy strings matching each sequence (e.g. "d:Bacteria,p:Firmicutes")

Returns a SintaxIndex ready for use with sintax or sintaxWithState.

proc classifyOneDir(query: string; idx: SintaxIndex; bootSubset: int = 32;
                    bootIters: int = 100): tuple[topCount: int, hit: SintaxHit] {.
    ...raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}

Classifies query against idx on the forward strand only.

Allocates a fresh workspace on each call; prefer sintaxWithState for batch processing to reuse allocations.

Parameters

  • query â€” DNA query sequence
  • idx â€” prebuilt SINTAX index from buildIndex
  • bootSubset â€” number of words sampled per bootstrap iteration (default: 32)
  • bootIters â€” number of bootstrap iterations (default: 100)

Returns a tuple of (topCount, hit) where topCount is the maximum word-match count seen and hit contains rank names and bootstrap confidences.

proc extractTaxRanks(tax: string): seq[string] {....raises: [], tags: [],
    forbids: [].}

Parses a comma-delimited taxonomy string into a list of rank strings.

Expects a string of the form "d:Bacteria,p:Firmicutes,c:Bacilli" and returns each rank:name token as a separate element.

proc initSintaxState(idx: SintaxIndex): SintaxState {....raises: [], tags: [],
    forbids: [].}

Allocates and returns a reusable SintaxState workspace for the given index.

Pass the returned state to sintaxWithState for each query to avoid repeated heap allocations in batch classification loops.

proc postingFirst(idx: SintaxIndex; word: uint16): int32 {....raises: [], tags: [],
    forbids: [].}
Returns the index of the first database sequence containing word, or -1 if the posting list is empty. 
proc postingLen(idx: SintaxIndex; word: uint16): int {....raises: [], tags: [],
    forbids: [].}
Returns the number of database sequences that contain 8-mer word. 
proc rc(s: string): string {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}

Returns the reverse complement of DNA/RNA sequence s.

Both upper- and lower-case bases are handled; non-ACGTU characters are passed through unchanged.

proc sintax(query: string; idx: SintaxIndex; bootSubset: int = 32;
            bootIters: int = 100): SintaxHit {....raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}

Convenience single-query SINTAX classification.

Allocates a fresh workspace, classifies query on both strands, and returns the best hit. For classifying many queries, prefer initSintaxState

  • sintaxWithState to reuse workspace allocations.

Parameters

  • query â€” DNA query sequence
  • idx â€” prebuilt SINTAX index from buildIndex
  • bootSubset â€” number of words sampled per bootstrap iteration (default: 32)
  • bootIters â€” number of bootstrap iterations (default: 100)
proc sintaxWithState(query: string; idx: SintaxIndex; state: var SintaxState;
                     bootSubset: int = 32; bootIters: int = 100): SintaxHit {.
    ...raises: [], tags: [], forbids: [].}

Classifies query using a pre-allocated SintaxState workspace.

Both strands are evaluated; the strand with the higher top word-match count wins. Use this proc in batch loops for best performance.

Parameters

  • query â€” DNA query sequence
  • idx â€” prebuilt SINTAX index from buildIndex
  • state â€” reusable workspace from initSintaxState
  • bootSubset â€” number of words sampled per bootstrap iteration (default: 32)
  • bootIters â€” number of bootstrap iterations (default: 100)
